Context:
The Fashion Business Industry program is an opportunity to enter the flourishing sector of the fashion industry focused on small- to medium-sized businesses. Students will be prepared for roles in managing a small fashion business and will gain understanding in textiles, garment construction, quality criteria, apparel merchandising, marketing, accounting, financial concepts, and other business skills.

Program Requirements: Students need a personal laptop or desktop computer with reliable internet access for synchronous classes.

Field Education Options: Students with a grade point average of 2.7 or higher may apply to take the Field Education elective in second year.

Career & Postgraduate Study Opportunities:
- Graduates can be employed in various fashion industry positions and have started their own successful businesses. Possible career paths include entrepreneur, store manager, production planner, operations manager, sales analyst, visual merchandise coordinator, marketing assistant, pre-production coordinator, transportation coordinator, warehouse assistant, wholesale sales agent, customer service associate, small manufacturing facility, fashion contracting firm, retail operation, wholesaler, sales agent, specialty boutique, and third-party logistics providers.
- Graduates who successfully complete the program may be eligible for admission to George Brown College postgraduate programs such as International Fashion Management (F412). Students with a grade point average of 3.5 or higher may be eligible for admission to fashion programs at other post-secondary institutions.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Fashion Business Industry Program F112 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The text provides information about the required courses for a Fashion program offered by the college. Here are the factual information extracted from the text:

- The college offers a Fashion program with courses spread across four semesters.
- Semester 1 courses include Visual Merchandising, World of Fashion, Introduction to Sewing and Drafting, Fabric Science: Textiles, Economics, Communicating Across Contexts (COMM 2000), a General Education Elective, and possibly COMM 1000 based on placement test results.
- Semester 2 courses include Fabric Analysis, Basic Accounting Principles, Apparel Construction Techniques 1, Fashion Merchandising and Buying, Apparel Marketing, a General Education Elective, and possibly additional program electives.
- Semester 3 courses include Apparel Drafting Techniques, Apparel Marketing – Advanced, Business Planning for Entrepreneur, Logistics and Costing for Fashion Industries, Adobe Illustrator, Apparel Construction Technique, Quality Assurance and Applications, and a program elective.
- Semester 4 courses include History of Costume, Financial Management for the Entrepreneur, Business Ethics, Retail Operations, a General Education Elective, and a program elective.
- Program electives may include Fashion Business Communication, Fashion Journalism – An Introduction, Fashion Advertising and Promotion, Textile Laboratory, Draping, and Portfolio.

Additionally, students should refer to the Transfer Guide for further information and may need to take COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 2000, which incurs an extra charge.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Fashion Business Industry Program F112 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The Textile Laboratory at the college offers various fashion-related courses including: FASH 2050 - Draping, FASH 2054 - Portfolio Development, FASH 2076 - Fashion Project and Event Planning, FASH 2077 - Textile Surface Design, FASH 2078 - Knitwear Product Development, FASH 1089 - Social Media for Fashion Marketing, FASH 1090 - Independent Study – Field Education, and FASH 1229 - Costume Production for Film and Theatre.

The graduates of this program are expected to be able to use basic apparel drafting and construction skills, industrial sewing machines, standard fashion industry computer software, manage daily operations in a retail enterprise, develop a business and finance plan, apply buying, merchandising, accounting practices, supply chain management, logistics, marketing plans, analyze economic, fashion, and industry trends, evaluate products by applying quality control processes, identify textile materials, assess their suitability and compatibility, and communicate effectively.

The tuition fees for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022 for domestic students is $4,427.00 and for international students it is $17,882.00. Fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and later dates. Books and additional supplies are not included in tuition fees and must be purchased separately.

The program is approved for OSAP (Ontario Student Assistance Program) funding for students who meet the eligibility criteria. For more information on international fees and related costs, visit the International Fees and Related Costs page.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Fashion Business Industry Program F112 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: The George Brown College offers a program in the School of Fashion and Jewellery. This program has admission requirements that include an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English (C or U), and either grade 11 math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Recommended skills in basic computer literacy and Word and Excel are also required. Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and math or consider upgrading to achieve the necessary credits. Course exemptions can be granted based on college or university credits, and more information can be found on the Transfer Guide. International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System and visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements. The program is offered at Casa Loma Campus, located at 160 Kendal Ave., Toronto, ON, Canada. Information sessions are held at this campus. For more information about the college, applicants can contact the School of Fashion and Jewellery at 416-415-5000 ext. 4840 or email fashionandjewellery@georgebrown.ca. The Contact Centre can also be reached at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002. International students can contact recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry on the International Contact Us page. The text includes phone numbers, email addresses, and locations of the college.

Context: "George Brown College offers on-campus information sessions and campus tours on a regular basis. Interested individuals can sign up for an info session or book a campus tour. The college provides programs in Fashion Management (F102), Fashion Techniques and Design (F113), International Fashion Management (Postgraduate Certificate) (F412). The fashion business industry program takes a multidisciplinary approach, preparing students for independence in the fashion industry. Students can demonstrate their individuality within the supportive community through awards, contests, research projects, and events. Prospective students can book campus tours, get answers to their questions by booking info sessions, and sign up to receive tailored resources to make their application process easier."
